instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: Disabling 2011 Macbook Pro GPU
threads.message: Has anyone tried or thought about disabling the bad GPU's in hardware?  I know there are some software solutions out there but they are pretty tricky and don't always work.  I wonder if there is a stuffing option on the boards (ie. <SIGNAL>GMUX_CFG0</SIGNAL>) or maybe just keep the PCI bus in reset by reconfiguring a resistor so the driver can't see it.

threads.title: Disabling 2011 Macbook Pro GPU
threads.message: Maybe at some point I will get to this. One thing you can try is removing <RESISTOR>R8795</RESISTOR>. Then check if <SIGNAL>PEX_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> stays high and if it forced to internal GFX. If it does not stay high you may need to pull it up to 3V with a 10K resistor. No guarantees this works though....

threads.title: Disabling 2011 Macbook Pro GPU
threads.message: i instralled windows on a gpu reflowed 2011 macbook, with osx it was very slow, but with windows its fast, i guess it is not using the dedicated GPU, or utilizing it differently.

threads.title: Disabling 2011 Macbook Pro GPU
threads.message: Being slow is probably a sensor issue, run ASD. But why bother, reflowed garbage will die in a few weeks/months again anyway. Unless you want to rip some one off by selling it quickly....
